snippet: A freighter on its way from Cuba to North Korea was found carrying missile-system components cloaked in a cargo of sugar, the Panamanian authorities said.
abstract: Panamanian authorities seize a freighter heading from Cuba to North Korea carrying what appears to be elements of an antiquated Soviet-era missile radar system amid more than 200,000 sacks of Cuban brown sugar; American and Panamanian officials are investigating why the North Korean crew members fought so hard to repel a boarding party as the ship tried to traverse the Panama Canal.

byline.original: By RICK GLADSTONE and DAVID E. SANGER
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Anne-Sophie Bolon from London; Raphael Minder from Paris; Gerry Mullany from Hong Kong; Choe Sang-hun from Seoul, South Korea; and Karla Zabludovsky from Mexico City.

lead_paragraph: A freighter on its way from Cuba to North Korea was found carrying missile-system components cloaked in a cargo of sugar, the Panamanian authorities said.

headline.main: Panama Seizes Korean Ship, and Sugar-Coated Arms Parts
headline.print_headline: Panama Seizes Korean Ship, And Sugar-Coated Arms Parts
